Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 11:24AM Chickenpants wrote: Just to let you gals know, the stereotactic went off without a hitch.  No problem.  I wasn't rushed through and everyone took the time to explain the whole procedure before we began.  I'm guessing we don't have the newest model for this type of test (ie prone table with the cutouts), but we did just fine.  The reason I had to wait so long is that the hospital only does this procedure once a week and they only do three patients each time.  Our hospital did 89 of these last year and Victoria (next closest large city on the Island) did 100.  The doc told me they'll be doing well in excess of 100 this year in Nanaimo alone.  That's 100 ladies in the area that do not have to undergo a surgical biopsy that is much more invasive and done under general when the majority of these ladies will be benign findings (72 of the 89 in 2010 were benign).  Also, we don't have breast surgeons, just general surgeons as our communities don't warrant it due to small numbers and I don't feel my case is compromised in any way, whatsoever.  I feel very well cared for.  My standard of care yesterday was A++.  Also, just to clarify, we don't have a "free" health care system as we pay higher taxes overall and we do have to pay provincial premiums for each family member, but all Canadians have access to medical care regardless of their social-economic standing or class.  Low income earners are subsidized on their premiums.  That being said, we are slowly starting to see the arrival of a two tiered system.  If we don't want to wait 6 months to a year for an MRI (my husband did recently), then we can choose to have the procedure done privately, but we pay out of our pockets or through additional insurance.  All critial/urgent cases are dealt with in a timely manner, thus the backlog.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 09:18AM Chickenpants wrote: I'm another Canadian and I live in a small community on Vancouver Island.  I had my screening mammo on June 28th, a call back for a diagnostic mammo two days later, for which the test was done one week after the initial screening.  Two days later, I followed up with my GP, then a rush to see the surgeon (within 2 days - I thought I was terminal because of the light speed that things were moving along, but oh no, it was due to the surgeon's holiday schedule!).  Next I had to wait to be notified of an US & Stereotactic biopsy (Aug. 5th & Aug. 9th respectively) by the hospital.  If the area in question was seen in the US, I would have remained at the hospital that day for a fine needle biopsy.  This was not the case, so on to the stereotactic today.  I have advised my doctors that with me going away for vacation on August 19th, being my test results may take 7-10 days, I don't want a call during my time away.  I will deal with it when I get back after Labour Day.  I feel more in control this way and 2-3 weeks more, at this stage, won't make any difference.  My mind is at peace, contrary to my original appearance in this website forum - thus "Chickenpants" as a user name.  I have my big girl panties on right now.... I must say I am amazed at the speed of which our American sisters are processed - start to finish is much quicker.  Do I think we are in jeopardy of having a lesser standard of care?  No, absolutely not.  I've learnt to deal much better with the time buffer allowing me to educate myself on all aspects of benign and early stage BC conditions.  I'm ok. I will agree with most posters about the waiting though - it's tough.  I found a couple of visits to a therapist to assist me with viewing the glass as half full, not completely empty has helped tremendously. Wish me courage today girls! Take care.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 08:58AM Chickenpants wrote: Hi there - I actually am afraid of water and what I did three weeks before the surgery is take a white water rafting trip in the East Kootenays.  I conquered my fears of both water and the rapids and had a great time with friends and family.  Note to self - forego the sun lotion on the underside of the legs as it makes sitting on the rubber raft a bit challenging.  You'll do fine.  I had my excisional via wire guide placement one week ago.  I am still sore and swollen.  I had my dressing changed yesterday and was a bit surprised by the length of the incision vs my small breast size, but other than that - good to go.  Now the hard part is waiting for the lab results.  I call it the "cruel clock". PM me if you want specifics. Take care.

Posts.Title: Unsuccessful biopsy JodyJ JodyJ

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 07:10AM Chickenpants wrote: Hi Cactus - was researching another topic when I saw your post and thought I would comment. My case was interesting that while the docs were focusing on my right breast for a small amount of DCIS and subsequent finding of LCIS, my left breast was not tested. Screening mammo caught the tiny calc clusters originally in my right breast - I am a very small breasted woman, so no lumps or abnormalities were ever felt or discovered by me. I was sent for a breast MRI due to the surprise finding of LCIS during the excisional biopsy, to see if anything else might be lurking. Something small and vague showed up in the left breast, but the doctors weren't overly concerned. I'm freaking inside and asked if they would do an ultrasound and needle biopsy on it, after the doctors suggestion we monitor it and re check again in six months. They scheduled it pretty quick and there followed a total shocker. Left breast had DCIS and IDC. You could have knocked me over. I feel totally responsible for saving myself. Had I waited another six months, the tumor would have required me to have chemo. I missed this by 1 mm. Just sayin... And no, you're not overreacting.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 06:41PM Chickenpants wrote: Hi dlm Been there, done that.  Just be aware that not all hospitals have the prone table with the holes in for the biopsy.  My community is smaller, so this procedure required me to lay on my side on a hospital gurney and then get me into position in the mammo paddles.  It's awkward, but very doable.  Being the chicken that I am, I was expecting far worse and on the scale of 1-10, it was about a 3 to 4 overall.  I could do this again.  A small amount of discomfort with the vacuum core extraction, even with local freezing, but I still joked with everyone and we had some laughs.  Worst of it was the bruising for 3-4 weeks.  My boob looked like I was wearing one half of a bikini top with a camo pattern.  If chickenpants can do it, you can too.

Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 12:21AM Chickenpants wrote: Hey ladies... The original author and starter of this thread/club making an appearance. My worry about ADH and the risks/monitoring did not last long - I was diagnosed with DCIS and an incidental finding of LCIS after an excisional biopsy and lumpectomy on September 22, 2011. That lead to an MRI post surgery to see what else was going on, for which they found something suspicious in the opposite breast. This little something was also making a joint appearance in an earlier US - one that I insisted on as I wanted both breasts tested. The LCIS/DCIS had made me a little nervous, but I was told not to worry too much about the new findings, likely some benign condition like a fibroadenoma, but it warranted a biopsy due to the busyness of the other breast. Incidentally, this new finding was never seen on any mammogram and it turned it to be a small amount of DCIS with an invasive component (IDC). A second lumpectomy on December 23, 2011 removed this new lesion and I had 7 lymph nodes removed via SNB. Nodes clear, thank goodness, but compromised margins on lesion removal. I have just finished up radiation therapy to both breasts with additional boosts to the invasive side. I survived and it wasn't all that bad. I paused in January to experience a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Survived that just fine too. There's a girl on these boards that has her signature quote something about if you fear the worst and it happens, then you've lived it twice. By the way, my recurrence risk is high, about 18% with my two primaries, so I will be taking my chances without hormone therapy because of the blod clot and stroke risk. my advise, relax and get on with living life. I tell everyone "I'm happy, I have no complaints!"
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2012 11:27PM Chickenpants wrote: Ah kittycan - you made the right choice and it's sitting well with you.  Not everyone would agree with such drastic measures when you don't even have cancer, but I understand very much so. The trick is to find the right solution to your problem and don't mind what others do or think.  At the end of the day, you can sleep like a baby and have that heavy burden removed. With my risk of recurrence I must learn to make peace with it.  It's still too soon for me and cancer is fresh in my mind.  The imp sitting on my shoulder watching me is going to get punted often and eventually won't bother me so much. Best wishes for a healthy recovery.
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 06:09PM Chickenpants wrote: Hey Carolyn, I'm right there with you - similar circumstances.  I'm in no risk group, nada... so like a kick in the stomach to be told this and have to deal with it.  My next two tests are ultrasound, then stereostatic biopsy Aug 5th & 9th.  You can follow my posts in this section for details and I, too, am in Canada - East Coast of Vancouver Island.  I find it good to have a support person come to my doctors appts & tests.   We can chat if you want. I'm going to make a point of staying out of the internet for the time being, but may pop in from time to time in this website.  Someone gave me advice to deal with the scary place of not knowing - refrain from googling as most of what you read doesn't apply to you. You can send me a private message. I'm here if you want to talk anytime.  Hang in there

I want my old life back, warts and all - yes, ignorance is bliss.
Posts.Title: Ever been treated like you've "Cried Wolf"? :( Rushell Lavender250

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2011 10:33AM Chickenpants wrote: I ended up in that elite "every six months" club.  I am 5 months out from the fateful screening mammo I had which showed a tiny (2 mm) suspicious area.  Anyhow, I have had multiple diagnostics and biopsies, an excisional lumpectomy, an MRI and we're still not done - the MRI showed an area of suspicion (7 mm) in the opposite breast, now another ultrasound guided biopsy scheduled.  I don't know how much more I can handle of not being in the know as to what's going on and what type of treatment I will ultimately need for my various conditions in my busy breasts (fibroadenomas, ADH, LCIS, DCIS), small breasted *34 small B*, and no family history or other risk factors other than being female.  Go figure.  My surgeon told me the other day, it's like a wild goose chase and where does it end?
Posts.Title: Six Months Rotation... sharkbait DocBabs

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 08:58PM Chickenpants wrote: I am a classic example of a woman, aged 51, no risk factors, screening mammos every 2 years since age 40, who has been diagnosed at the earliest stage of BC.  In fact, when my doctor told me to start my screening mammos at age 40, I didn't do it right away and debated whether I should or shouldn't bother, due to very small risk and small breasts - I thought for sure, if something were wrong, I would be able to tell pretty quick as there's not much to me. Well, at age 51&1/2, I had a recall for digital mammo, that went from suspicious calc cluster on digital, to ultrasound (findings multiple cysts & fibroadenoma), stereotactic VA core biopsy (findings ADH), then excisional/lumpectomy (findings DCIS 2.5 mm, LCIS 3 mm - LCIS was incidental finding).  Clean margins, but then on to MRI, both breasts (findings suspicious area on opposite breast), then ultrasound guided core biopsy.  OK - enough and we're still not sure the extent of what I have and how I will be treated (if at all).  Still waiting for latest biopsy results. My surgeon calls this "the wild goose chase".  How far do you go and once you have information, how do you act.  Depending on what you read or who you consult with, it is either cancer or pre-cancer.  Too small for radiation, but now high risk of possible future breast cancer warrants high risk surveillance for the rest of my life. My point is, on the one hand I'm grateful for the early detection, but on the other hand, the physical and psychological trauma for this ongoing wild goose chase is hard to take.  It's such a grey area.  I will bet the cummulative cost of all of these procedures is a lot on our social health care system.  The hardest thing about it all is if I had done no screenings or diagnostics, there is a very good chance that I would live out my life never getting BC, nor dying of it.  But now, I have the information.  What will I do with it?
Posts.Title: Breast cancer screening guide says skip exams Chickenpants Chickenpants

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 01:02AM Chickenpants wrote: Hi Kimmer - I'm a numbers gal and I found this interesting.  If you want to read the whole article on risk as it applies to DCIS, it certainly sheds some light on how they come up with the numbers.  The website is www.dcis.info and go to the section "Understanding Risk".  Here's an excerpt: You may have heard that the average woman's risk of invasive breast cancer is about 1 in 8 or 12%. This is the risk up to age 80. Of this 12% risk, 2% occurs by age 50. From 50 to 70 the average woman's risk of breast cancer is 6% and from 70 to 80 it is 4%. The 2% plus 6% plus 4% add up to 12%. As a woman goes through each age without a diagnosis of breast cancer, she leaves behind the risk associated with it. To put risk in another context, you are not at risk of being in an accident on a road you traveled yesterday. You can only be at risk for today's roads and the roads you'll travel in the years ahead. The article explains how risk is actually assessed and how it is often misleading to the layman in how the results are displayed. It's not specific to DCIS, but most studies that produce percentage results.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 11:34AM Chickenpants wrote: Thanks for your postings ladies.  I haven't been on the boards for a bit.  My ADH, upon excisional biopsy Sept. 22nd, ended up as 2.5 mm of DCIS and incidental findings of 3 mm LCIS.  All clean margins for both lesions, no sign of invasive cancer and off for my MRI today. Because of this condition, one never knows who will get a recurrence or worse, and who will not, so I'm often torn between doing nothing from this point on and taking my chances, or doing everything such as PBMX.  I have to have a referral to the cancer clinic for consultation.  It is unlikely I am a candidate for radiation as the lesion was so small, but I'm not a drug person either.  Would opt for more surgery before having to take a hormone therapy.  Quality of life I guess is a personal decision. Anyhow, will keep you all posted. Take care.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 10:25PM Chickenpants wrote: Hi Cats - I think you're getting this test ahead of me, so you can be the big sister and hold my hand.  I know what you mean about rushing you through.  My first two mammograms were only days apart and I was beside myself at that point, then followed by the urgency to see my GP, then the surgeon.  I asked the secretary why I was such an urgent case... was I going to die soon - she said it was the doctor's schedule and he was due to go on holidays, so wanted the tests back beforehand. My mind thought I had a walnut sized calc cluster and a BIRAD 4 rating.  Surgeon said it was 2 mm cluster and about a 3 rating.  My mind was eased somewhat.  Still scared of the what ifs...
Posts.Title: Sterotactic Biopsy...SCARED! Cats134 Cats134

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 09:15AM Chickenpants wrote: Hi julz... Here's hoping you get some good news. My news was always bad, so I thought. If there was an 80 or 90% chance of good news, I swung the other way. It's very hard mentally. What they did to my body was only 20% of the whole picture, my mental end of things was most affected. I found it helpful to talk with a counsellor at the Cancer Agency. I must now learn to live with my high risk of recurrence as the tamoxifen is only predicted to give me a 30% reduction to about 12% recurrence and has too many risks and side effects for the small amount of gain. I did not require chemo due to my "lazy" cancer's mitotic rate, but grade 2 with necrosis, so thus rads for both sides. I also found it helpful to consult with a naturopathic oncologist for ways to improve my diet and add some beneficial supplements. I have chosen this over drugs and perhaps the ADH ladies should look at doing prevention diets and gaining peace of mind that they are doing all they can. I have an excellent book from the naturopath onco, if anyone wants the title, please PM me.
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 10:31AM Chickenpants wrote: Wow julz, you have lots going on. You're busy, breasts are busy...when do you start rads? It's not all that bad. I was expecting worse, now one month out after having both sides radiated, you wouldn't be able to tell by looking at me. The SNB was the worst of everything they did to me. The area is full of nerves that get damaged during the procedure. I was doing too much too soon and ended up with a stubborn seroma which needed draining a couple of times, but it kept returning. Mostly better now, six months out. So take it easy. A big hug for ya and keep us posted. There are lots of good threads in this site to offer support. Take care.

Posts.Title: Sterotactic Biopsy...SCARED! Cats134 Cats134

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 04:55PM - edited Oct 2, 2011 04:55PM by Chickenpants Hey... I can sympathize with you.  I've had all of this done and more, but just not in one day.  I totally understand the pain grenade too.  I'm not sure how I would have faired if I had to go into all of these tests unprepared.  It's scary.  Do you have close friends or family you can talk to.  It's good to have that support.  I call these people in my life my "posse". It's good to keep busy, so unless you're physically ill, go into work and the time will pass quicker until you know the results.  I think it's not proper for the hospital/lab staff to scare you that way.  Support is one thing, but it's your doctor's responsibility to talk to you about your condition - at least that's what we do in Canada.  None of the x-ray or ultrasound techs discuss my findings or give an opinion and they tell me that, even though I'm likely to ask anyway. Not only is this a good venting space, it's great for support.  I, myself, like to be informed, so I do research on my own condition.  I find it helps when I meet with my surgeon to discuss findings and next steps. I'm sorry to hear about your dad.  These things never seem to pick a good time to occur... Take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: Hoping for the best is hard... PhunkyM Babsplus5

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 12:57PM - edited Feb 15, 2012 01:00PM by Chickenpants Aza - interesting article, but there's no date on it.  This was just published?  The other article that's interesting is the one on the findings of radiation treatment - the one about the radiation changing the healthy cells and turning them into cancer causing ones. It's over in the radiation forum.  Really, it just puts so much uncertainty on if we're doing the right thing by getting treatment of any kind.  Link to article: http://www.cancer.ucla.edu/Index.aspx?page=644&recordid=560&returnURL=%2Findex.aspx
